title: ADR: robotics integration architecture — control-plane vs edge-gateway split, protocol selection
body: Document three-layer architecture decision: (1) Portarium control/decision plane (policy, approvals, audit); (2) Portarium execution plane (workers/adapters, containment); (3) Edge robot gateway (robotics middleware or PLC interface, local safety interlocks, real-time constraints). Decision: Portarium issues high-level goals only; servo loops and safety stops remain at edge. Include Mermaid architecture diagram. Protocol selection per class: gRPC edge gateway (general), ROS 2 Action bridge (robot-native), MQTT (IoT/PLC), OPC UA (industrial). AC: ADR in docs/adr/; references bead-0497 atlas; unblocks domain port family and adapter beads.

title: ADR: robotics safety boundary — what Portarium governs vs what the edge safety controller must own
body: Define and document the safety boundary between Portarium and edge safety functions. Portarium governs: policy tier gating, approvals, audit evidence, idempotency/retry control, mission scheduling. Edge safety controller owns: E-stop, interlocks, collision avoidance, speed limits, geofence enforcement, real-time closed-loop control. Reference: ISO 12100, ISO 10218, ISO/TS 15066, ISO 13849-1. AC: ADR in docs/adr/ with RACI table; safety functions listed per owner; security and safety interaction noted; machinery compliance timeline (EU 2027, UK, US/OSHA) referenced.

title: Testing: evidence-chain verification under adversarial retries for robot actions
body: Prove retry storms and duplicate commands do not produce unsafe duplicate physical actions. Scenarios: (1) same mission idempotency key submitted twice simultaneously — second call returns existing missionId, no duplicate gateway call; (2) network failure mid-dispatch — retry produces same outcome, evidence chain consistent; (3) partial execution followed by retry — plan idempotencyKey prevents re-execution; (4) adversarial replay with modified payload rejected. AC: all 4 scenarios covered; evidence entries consistent under fault injection; duplicate-command incidence 0 in test suite.

title: Domain: WorkforceMember aggregate — operational resource overlay on WorkspaceUser
body: Introduce WorkforceMember as a domain aggregate that represents a person as an assignable, executable resource. It is not a replacement for WorkspaceUser (identity/RBAC) or Party (canonical cross-system person); it is an operational overlay. Fields: WorkforceMemberId (branded primitive), linkedUserId (WorkspaceUserId reference), displayName, capabilities (string[] from controlled vocab), availabilityStatus (available | busy | offline), queueMemberships (WorkforceQueueId[]), tenantId. Domain rules: a WorkforceMember must link to an active WorkspaceUser; capabilities are immutable by the member themselves (admin-only); availability is self-managed. Events: WorkforceMemberRegistered, WorkforceMemberCapabilityUpdated, WorkforceMemberAvailabilityChanged. Acceptance: aggregate + value objects + branded primitive; unit tests for all domain rules; zero infra imports in domain/.

title: Domain: HumanTask value object — formalise Manual-only as tracked assignment with completion signal
body: Formalise the Manual-only execution tier as a HumanTask: a domain value object (or thin aggregate) that captures a unit of human work produced by a workflow step. The glossary already states 'Portarium may create/track a linked task and wait on a completion signal' for Manual-only — this bead makes that concrete. Fields: HumanTaskId (branded), workItemId, runId, stepId, assigneeId (WorkforceMemberId | null), groupId (WorkforceQueueId | null), description, requiredCapabilities (string[]), status (pending | assigned | in-progress | completed | escalated), dueAt (Temporal.Instant | null), completedAt, completedById, evidenceAnchorId. Domain rules: completed tasks are immutable; escalation sets assigneeId=null and requeues to group; status transitions are explicit (state machine). Events: HumanTaskCreated, HumanTaskAssigned, HumanTaskCompleted, HumanTaskEscalated. Acceptance: value object/aggregate + state machine + unit tests; no infra imports.

title: Domain: WorkforceQueue aggregate — capability routing and group assignment
body: Introduce WorkforceQueue as an aggregate that groups workforce members by capability and routes HumanTasks. Fields: WorkforceQueueId (branded), name, requiredCapabilities (string[]), memberIds (WorkforceMemberId[]), routingStrategy (round-robin | least-busy | manual), tenantId. Domain rules: a task routed to a queue must have requiredCapabilities that are a subset of the queue's requiredCapabilities; routing selects from available members only; if queue is empty or all members busy, task stays pending. Events: WorkforceQueueCreated, WorkforceQueueMemberAdded, HumanTaskQueued. Acceptance: aggregate + routing logic unit tests; domain rule coverage; no infra imports.

title: App: AssignWorkforceMember use-case — assign a workforce member to Work Item or HumanTask
body: Implement the AssignWorkforceMember use-case in src/application/. Handles two scenarios: (1) assigning a WorkforceMember as ownerUserId on a WorkItem; (2) assigning a WorkforceMember to a pending HumanTask (directly or via queue routing). Steps: validate member is active and has required capabilities for the task; update assignment; emit WorkforceMemberAssigned domain event; write evidence record (assignment event as append-only evidence entry). Acceptance: use-case class with port interfaces; unit tests for happy path + capability mismatch + unavailable member; evidence record written; no infra imports in application/.

Acceptance: use-case with port interfaces; unit tests for happy path, wrong-assignee rejection, already-completed idempotency; evidence record written; run-resume signal emitted (can be a stub port in application layer).
